perturbation.original_text: Without limiting or qualifying the Sponsor's liabilities, obligations, or indemnities, before the Event, the Sponsor will obtain, at its sole cost and expense, a comprehensive general liability insurance policy from a company acceptable to ANTHEMIC and authorized to do business in the state of Illinois with limits of no less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and $2,000,000.00 as an annual aggregate. The insurance mentioned in the preceding sentence will name ANTHEMIC as additional insured. The Sponsor will also maintain any statutorily required workers compensation insurance. The Sponsor will provide ANTHEMIC with properly executed certificates of insurance before the Sponsor provides any products or services at the Event, and the insurance will contain a provision that it cannot be reduced or cancelled unless and until the insurance company notifies ANTHEMIC. Any third party that performs services on the Event grounds on behalf of the Sponsor will be required to satisfy the same insurance requirements as provided in this section.
perturbation.changed_text: Without limiting or qualifying the Sponsor's liabilities, obligations, or indemnities, before the Event, the Sponsor will obtain, at its sole cost and expense, a general liability insurance policy from a company acceptable to ANTHEMIC and authorized to do business in the state of Illinois. The insurance mentioned in the preceding sentence will name ANTHEMIC as additional insured. The Sponsor will also maintain workers compensation insurance as needed. The Sponsor will provide ANTHEMIC with certificates of insurance before the Sponsor provides any products or services at the Event.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of 'comprehensive', the specific liability limits ($1,000,000.00 per occurrence and $2,000,000.00 as an annual aggregate) and the provision that the insurance cannot be reduced or cancelled until the insurance company notifies ANTHEMIC significantly weakens the insurance requirements. It also makes the workers compensation requirement more vague. This creates a legal contradiction with Illinois state law that mandates specific minimum coverage amounts for commercial activities and notification requirements for insurance policy changes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Commercial General Liability Insurance Requirements

perturbation.original_text: LIMITATION OF DAMAGES. EXCEPT FOR INDEMNIFICATION  OBLIGATIONS DUE TO LIABILITIES TO THIRD PARTIES, NOTWITHSTANDING ANY PROVISION CONTAINED IN THIS AGREEMENT TO THE CONTRARY, NO PARTY TO THIS AGREEMENT WILL BE LIABLE TO ANY OTHER PARTY TO THIS AGREEMENT FOR ANY INCIDENTAL, INDIRECT, SPECIAL, CONSEQUENTIAL OR PUNITIVE DAMAGES (INCLUDING DAMAGES FOR LOSS OF USE, POWER, BUSINESS GOOD WILL, REVENUE OR PROFIT, NOR FOR INCREASED EXPENSES, OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) ARISING OUT OF OR RELATED TO THE PERFORMANCE OR NON PERFORMANCE OF THIS AGREEMENT UNLESS THE DAMAGES AROSE DUE TO A PARTY'S GROSS NEGLIGENCE OR WILLFUL BREACH OF THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.changed_text: LIMITATION OF DAMAGES. NOTWITHSTANDING ANY PROVISION CONTAINED IN THIS AGREEMENT TO THE CONTRARY, NO PARTY TO THIS AGREEMENT WILL BE LIABLE TO ANY OTHER PARTY TO THIS AGREEMENT FOR ANY INCIDENTAL, INDIRECT, SPECIAL, CONSEQUENTIAL OR PUNITIVE DAMAGES (INCLUDING DAMAGES FOR LOSS OF USE, POWER, BUSINESS GOOD WILL, REVENUE OR PROFIT, NOR FOR INCREASED EXPENSES, OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) ARISING OUT OF OR RELATED TO THE PERFORMANCE OR NON PERFORMANCE OF THIS AGREEMENT UNLESS THE DAMAGES AROSE DUE TO A PARTY'S GROSS NEGLIGENCE OR WILLFUL BREACH OF THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'EXCEPT FOR INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS DUE TO LIABILITIES TO THIRD PARTIES,' the limitation of damages clause is broadened to include indemnification obligations. This directly contradicts standard legal practice and case law which typically holds parties responsible for indemnifying third-party claims, even when consequential damages are limited between the contracting parties. This omission introduces significant legal risk and can be seen as a violation of good faith dealing under California law, the governing law of the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California law on Indemnification and Third-Party Liability

perturbation.original_text: Governing Law and Venue. This Agreement is to be governed and construed according to the laws of the State of California without regard to conflicts of law. The proper exclusive venue for resolution of any dispute related to this Agreement is only in Los Angeles, California, and both parties consent to jurisdiction and venue in Los Angeles, California.
perturbation.changed_text: Governing Law and Venue. This Agreement is to be governed and construed according to the laws of the State of California without regard to conflicts of law. The venue for resolution of any dispute related to this Agreement will be determined at ANTHEMIC's sole discretion.
perturbation.explanation: By changing the clause to allow ANTHEMIC to determine the venue for dispute resolution, the agreement removes the sponsor's right to a pre-determined, mutually agreed-upon venue. While parties can generally agree on venue, some states have consumer protection laws that restrict or invalidate venue clauses that force consumers (or smaller entities) to litigate in distant or inconvenient locations. If VNUE (the sponsor) were considered a smaller, less sophisticated entity compared to ANTHEMIC, this clause could be challenged as unconscionable under California consumer protection laws. This is especially true if ANTHEMIC chose a venue that made it excessively difficult for VNUE to pursue a claim. This creates a legal contradiction regarding fair business practice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Protection Laws regarding Venue and Unconscionability
